The Sabbath Visitor,
Cincinnati, Ohio.
Jacob Voorsanger, Editor.
Houston, Texas, April 22[,] 1886
Rev S. Morais
My dear Sir

In accordance with the promise expressed in my
last letter I write you freely in reply to your valued favor of April 7.

1. I must repeat the assertion I am not as black as I am painted. To be sure,
it is the easiest thing, especially on the part of the zealots of whom we have too many
to misrepresent both motives, and the results flowing therefrom, I am not disposed
to shield myself be [y] hind a hypocritical denial of the facts, or some glittering mean
ingless sophistries. All I want of you, if you have finished this letter is to judge
me upon the face of the statements therein contained and to still believe that a
fervent love of and for Judaism, a keen anxiety to uphold the banner of the
Thora are still the motives that guide my conduct. The first intimation you
received of my having "made common cause with the radicals" was doubt-
lessly when I publicly defended the action of my conference in endorsing the
Pittsburg platform. Am I right? To explain my defense you must know
the minor[?] history of the Southern endorsement. Believe me, never have I be-
held more earnestness than in our December conference. The day before the
meeting the Ex. Comm. heard Mr. Guttheim's ^ Annual report, in which there was
an unqualified endorsement of Pittsburg. A long and earnest discussion
took place. For my part, I bitterly upbraided the organizers of theis
Pittsburg movement, and held, as I did subsequently, that the policy
of the gathering was unwise and inexpedient, and that the platform
as a basis of religious belief was unavailable, because too philosophically

and ambiguously expressed. Still, there were the three fundamental doctr-
ines of Aebo[?], [Hebrew] and [Hebrew] clearly expressed, and in
so far I also subscribed. But I held that the wisest policy would be to ignore
the Pittsburg conference. Mr. Guttheim, a man who, next to you has ever my
complete esteem and veneration claimed, I think justly, that an ignoring of
the Pittsburg conference
would be a black insult, and imply a want of policy
on our partly. The country was just ringing with the affair, the South looked
to their assembled ministers for guidance in the matter, and we must express
an opinion favorable or otherwise. The discussion lasted till deep in the
night, Leucht, Berkowitz (of the college) and myself, holding the one opinion,
Mr Guttheim and Hecht the other. We finally agreed that the President's
report should be so modified as to embody his consent to the proposition,
that the Southern Conference allowed no one to control their action as
regards [Hebrew] or [Hebrew]. If you will look at the report, which I sent you
you will find it so expressed. Subsequently I was on the committee to report
upon the suggestions embodied in the president's report, and if you will
look at the Committee report, the past alluding to the Pittsburg con-
ference I think you will discover my style. The task before us was either
to reject or to endorse the P. platform, and conscientiously I could
not oppose the platform if my simples[?], concerning [Hebrew] were satisfied.
The discussions in conference were long, earnest but more heated, and
there was a unanimity as regards the platform yet a tinge of
conservatism in the unanimous--but 2"adoption of the com-
mittee's clause, that [Hebrew] and [Hebrew] were as binding now as they ever
were. To show you how men may be misinterpreted:When the two
who were against adopting this clause demanded an opinion on the
subjection of Mr Guttheim ( the chair[
insered by author] my venerable friend said that
he could not express an opinion, but were he on the floor he would
vote for the committees report! Thus the Pittsburg platform found
its way in our conference, with the reservation mentioned, and having
committed myself, I felt obliged to defend our actions in the Be[...]
especially when the Record"with that wonderful logic for which chu[?]-
ma[?] is celebrated--[Hebrew]--proved that we had condemned the Pittsburgers! So much for this.

The Sabbath Visitor,
Cincinnati, Ohio.
Jacob Voorsanger, Editor.

2. But, this is not all I have to say, and since I accord you full authority
to be my judge, you must know all. We have corresponded for years, and
it has never been a secret to you that I am always struggling, always
thinking, always praying to find the right way. Had I remained at home I might
have been a good, pious, unquestioning semi-Hasid, or else a performing
sceptic as I have known many a Talmudist to be. But I came to cast my lot with
my brethren in America, I began to move in an atmosphere strange to me
at first; and being a mere youth, yet shrewd enough to take an occasional
peep[?] in the future, I perfected my German studies and auto-didactically
began to read that immense, wonderful [?] of German-Jewish literature, that
fairly equals that of our Spanish sages. My dear friend, need I tell you that
such reading must necessarily change youthful convictions? Yet for
along time I could hardly tell wherein I had changed. The conservatism
of my native home was too strong an armor, nor has it yet lost its force.
Come, let us compare ideas, and you shall judge whether I too am a
"radical" though I am in this congregation, as you have been told. I have
read Kuenen[?] and Willhausen[?] and Noldeke[?] and Robertson Smith, and
a [?] of other authors. If I tell you that my faith is strong in
these truths, of which Albo says correctly, they are the pillars of Juda-
ism, and our religion stands or falls with them, can I not allow
myself the latitude of a scholar? You have never met a scoffing
word in any of my writings. In my Sabbath School lessons I have ever
been conservative, assuming the standpoint of revelation, treating every
fact of history as traditionally received. But that my private opinions tend
in different directions I do not deny, nor am I disposed to gloss over
my scepticism. Remember, I am in no sceptic on the cardinal points of
Judaism. These are as firm in my mind as the foundations of
mountains. But is a belief in the Thorah being of Moses a "cardinal
doctrine of Judaism"? Maimonides has indeed[Hebrew]
and also [Hebrew], and do either of these doctrines either
prove that Moses wrote the whole Thora, or that his having written
it is a continual point of Judaism? I am somewhat surprised at
the tenacity with which you hold this one point as cardinal. Our Thora
in the Thorath Moshe, but must it be in its entirety? Noldeke[?] gives

proof positive, that at keast two points of the Zend-Avesta[?] is written
in a language, with which Zorvaster[?] was unacquainted. Yet it is the Zoro-
astrian book I f I believe that Deuteronomy is older than Exodus, and
that Genesis is of more recent origin than either, can I not be firm
nevertheless in my belief that the divine wisdom is laid down in these
books? And supposing I have serious doubts as to the ^veracity if supernatural-
ism, am I an isolated case? Did or diid not Saadjah Ea[?]
([(Hebrew]) endeavor to explain that Revelation
was the highest conception of reason? Or if we speak of text critic-
ism is there anything new in it? What else is the greatest part
of Medrash but these text criticism? To be sure, it was different from
ours, and I beg you to believe that I am not trying to hoodwink
you. Our criticism is destructive of the sacred character of the
scriptures"but believe me again I never carry my opinions in the
Synagogue or the schools. I think of these matters largely as you think
of the Shulhan Aruka[?]. Now, in what do differ from you? Possibly
in any belief that the Bible is not [Hebrew], that it is a book of
gradual developments, in which compilers have had a larger share
than Moses. But, there are technical divergencies. The
main thing would be whether we can agree upon the manner
and method of propagating our beloved religion. And these
I say boldly, the conservatives do not believe a little more than
we do, some of them possibly less. I do believe in God and His
revelation as embodied in and outside the Scriptures, I believe
further that he rewards and punishes, and that He will take
care of me when I am no more. I believe that He has
reserved a [Hebrew] and [Hebrew] for Israel to be a [Hebrew]. Do you
believe more? Shall we haggle over a [Hebrew]? neither
of which doctrines were accepted by Albo? Shall we
split on the question of being [Hebrew] or [Hebrew] and lecture
one another as Ben Shesheth did the good pious Eali-
papa? Now, you know what kind of a radical I am, I stand
squarely upon the rock of Judaism, and think of the relative
doctrines as millions before me may have done. We are in
ths midst of a trife which has a good many amusing

The Sabbath Visitor,
Cincinnati, Ohio.
Jacob Voorsanger, Editor.

features. If you had seem one day before yesterday [Hebrew], sitting
in mys study surrounded by these Russian peddler, to whom I
read a few pages of the [Hebrew] in the [Hebrew], you would have thought
I was a good old Bachur[?]. Yet, because my ideas are more liberal
as regards unessentials, and because my association as radical,
must I need be one of those of whom it is said [Hebrew]? I do
not say [Hebrew]!

3.You say that you hoped I would become an honor to intelligent conser-
vativism. I beg you, if you have still faith in me, to hope so still, and I will
not disappoint you. My alliance is with the radical means that I am
seeking among them what the conservatives refuse me, and that
is, [Hebrew], liberty of thought. You are too noble, too honest to fully perceive
the plots of New York! I pray you, once more, let me speak frankly
to you. You are my old friend, and I would be unworthy of the name
if I were not to explain my standpoint to you. I am a journalist
by intuition , that mean I have the leaven of this world about me. Yours are the [crossed-out[Hebrew]] [Hebrew] and therefore you have been all
your life the [Hebrew]. Now, what could I, with my ideas for
the unification of all Jewish interests in this country, do in this
singular alliance, of which you are said to be the principium et
fons? Cast about me, and I find that this alliance has other
component parts. With the largest part, of the Polish Hassidistic
element of New York you have as little sympathy as I have. They
will treat you, upon intimate acquaintance as the German-Ital-
ian Rabbis Juda Menz and Joseph Kolon treated Messer Leon and
Del Medigo, and as the named Rabbi of Paisa treated the
pious Capsali of Constantinople. Do you think I could conceive
of an alliance between my brave, consistent old friend and the
scandal mongers of the Allen Street Beth Ham'[?] Medrash? Never! They are not of your kind. Their Judaism is not yours or mine. It is
Catholicism with Hebrew letters, Parseeism brought over to New
York. Deduct that element. Would you train your Seminarians
to serve them? And if you did, do you suppose they would

accept your scientifically trained Rabbis instead of their Polish Has-
sidism or do you even think that you could induce a graduate to
be slowly pestered to death amongst the ritualistic Shochatim abounding
in the East End? I can conceive of no lasting alliance between you and
their people? They are outside of any calculation. I never forget
[Hebrew] I will serve them, ameliorate their condition,
anything;-- only as long as the influx from Russia continues
I cannot conceive the possibility of raising them to the high
intellectual status of an Italian Rabbi, be he orthodox to the core!

Next, the second element of your alliance is not to my liking.
It is composed of men who half between reform and orthodoxy. Of
these you have but a few. Jastrow and Szold, representing a large
following stand back. Their position is inexplicable. They are neither
[Hebrew] or [Hebrew]. But Dr Kohut"yes I advise him as much as you
do for his learning and wonderful versatility. But he has unfurled
his banner too soon. He broke the staff over our heads before he
was a month in this country, before he had the faintest conception
of American reform. A man so hasty of judgment may be a. bookworm, but not a leader. As I wrote you, his position in Germany
is that of a reformer, hated by the Neoorthodox, whom leaders, Hirsch[?],
Hildesheim[?] and Lehman have long since reckoned him amongst
the irredeemable. Your third element is represented by a few
English gentlemen whose policy seems to introduce neology. I
am afraid of it. The holy Zohar, the holy [Hebrew], the holy [Hebrew],the
holy Gaon so and so, this is the phrasseology of the neo-ortho-
dox and faintly echoed by their English cousins, the Messrs
Mendez! You, with your fine, firm consistency are a reformer of
the deepest dye in the eyes of Lehman and his peers. Why? Be-
cause you have more than once admitted that you would not
object to a condensed ritual or an abbreviated Shulchan Aruth
on the basis of our modern wants! That is a crime. In addition
I believe the Mendez' are working, not [Hebrew] but for position, for
self -elevation, and with such men I can have no fellowship.
Call a convention of Rabbis and Ministers, place before them

The Sabbath Visitor,
Cincinnati, Ohio.
Jacob Voorsanger, Editor.

your pure Judaism, your lofty conceptions, and I take God to witness of
any innermost conviction that you will find more adherents amongst
the reformers than amongst the Kohut-Mendez-Jastrow coterie! Your
basis is [Hebrew]; their's is opposition to the west as the
basis of self-elevation, and if I am wrong in my opinions I hope
that God and they may forgive me. Now, what else is left for me. I
must join a party. My position is too uncertain to remain isolated. I
still believe that I shall make headway with my progressive, not
aggressive idea of a conservative Judaism in America on the basis
of a complete alienation from all semblance of Hassidism,
--and this means the work of a lifetime; but I must have friends,
in course of time followers, and"pardon me again, my friend,--
either your schemes or mine! Far better Abram Isaacs with his
honest idealism. He believes that the laymen will accomplish wonders.
Perhaps he is right. But this alliance of yours, will it accomplish what
I am praying for all the days of my life, what I have confessed to
myself with bitter mortification I am incapable of accomplishing
--will it restore devotion in the households, bring back the people to
the throne of the Sabbath queen, fill our pews with devout
worshipers? Emil Hirsch's pews are crowded on Sunday, and Fred
Mendez, who permits the sale of [Hebrew] accompanied by organ music
has a thin guard on the Sabbath day. Can your alliance do
all this? Another thing. Have the graduates of the Hebrew Union
College turned out so badly, that they must be warred against? The
platform of your new college is not materially different from
that of Cincinnati. You cannot have an old style [Hebrew], nor, I
know well, do you intend it. And if you admit science and philosophy
you forever bar the mind against believing in an infallible, un-
allayed[?] and unchangeable law or tradition!

I must close now, for fe lest you may think I forget that I am
merely writing a letter. To my mind, radicals and conservatives
are both striving to find the proper means for restoring Israel's

faith, and if I am standing on the one side and you on the other,
I am convinced we strive for the same object. Only do me the justice to
believe that my fealty to God and my faith has not diminished
nor am I estranged from those things to which I have ever been
passionately attached. I believe I am laboring in the interest
of intelligent conservatism though I seek[?] for the means
amongst the radicals. Possibly after you have read this
letter this will not sound paradoxical to you. I am doing my
best for my people, I labor to instruct and improve them, and in
so far at least I am in the right path.

Let me soon hear from you that you have read this long letter
and that my frankness has not offended you. I would sooner
lose your favor by frankness that retain it by hypocrisy,
though I know you well enough, that you can both forgive frankness
and detect hypocrisy. Awaiting your answer, then, I am as
always

Faithfully Yours
Jacob Voorsanger

NB. My dear wife and children, are, thank God, in their usual state of
fine health. The "troubles in the nest"may have some influence on my
future. But I believe I am booked for San Francisco. Of this more in
a future letter.
